author: potuz
content: I'm not sure were to post this so I'll try here. I want to get a feeling as to whats the weight of "not breaking any contract" when reviewing EIPs. My impression is that there's a strong bias in the community that we should not break any contract unless there's a security issue or a very strong case for it. Then I'm faced with 3074 and it's not clear what's the path forward. I figured the best I can do now in my free time is give an unbiased view on these EIPs.

author: sky.cactus
content: Historically there has been *incredibly* strong bias against breaking existing contracts.  See 2930.

author: sky.cactus
content: (which exists solely to avoid breaking contracts)

author: sky.cactus
content: That being said, arguably the switch from DIFFICULTY to RANDAOMIX was breaking (though the expectation was that it wouldn't actually break anyone).

author: ryanleeschneider
content: Do the "people claiming their nft contract will be broken" mean that their contracts won't be compatible w/ 3074, or that 3074 will introduce a means for someone to exploit or otherwise grief their contract?  If it's the later I definitely sympathize, blockchains are billed as immutable so I would be upset if an invariant that held when I deployed my contract was changed during a later fork.  Not sure what the solution is but some sort of means for contracts to opt-in to new functionality seems useful.  Maybe EOF v2 can have some sort of section where a contract describes what sort of invariants it relies on, and future behavior changes have to respect that metadata?

author: sky.cactus
content: A lot of people have contracts that are already vulnerable, but allowing EOAs to execute code makes it more obvious.

author: sky.cactus
content: `require(tx.origin === msg.sender)` in particular is almost always a sign your contract is already broken, but in a way most people think it is protected.

author: sky.cactus
content: Some people use this as a really bad mechanism for reentrancy protection, which any auditor worth their salt will warn against.
